Authors: Thomas C. Harrington, Paul J. Zambino
Title:
Correspondence of isozyme characterization with morphology in
the asexual genus Leptographium and taxonomic implications.
Abstract:
The similarity of 88 isolates of 27 species of
Leptographium was studied using enzyme electrophoresis. UGPMA cluster
analysis of similarity matrices (Nei genetic identity, I) generated from
data of 267 electrophoretic forms (electromorphs) of 15 enzymes showed a
close correspondence between electrophoretic similarity and morphology.
Isolates of a species had high similarity and clustered at I  0.60, and
in cases where different taxa clustered at I > 0.60, an examination
of the morphology and history of the isolates suggested conspecificity.
Isozyme characterization was also useful for identifying the extent of
morphologic variation within versus between species and for comparing
isolates with degenerate morphology after prolonged culture.
